doc.title: Minerals Therapeutics Inc. (MLYS: Keystone) Takeaways from Our NDR w/ MLYS Mgmt + AZN's Baxdrostaf Webina
doc.source_uri: 2025-09-02/Mineralys Therapeutics Inc. (MLYS)_ Key Takeaways from Our NDR w_ MLYS Mgmt + AZN’s Baxdrostat Webinar_2025-09-02

passages.text: Following AZN's presentation of baxdrostaf Ph. 3 BaxHTN results at ESC 2025 (see our recap note) and its subsequent Meet the Management at ESC 2025 webinar, we hosted a dinner NDR with MLYS mgmt + its KOL (Dr. Manish Saxena) to discuss the implications for lourndrostat. Our NDR discussion covered many topics including: 1) lourndrostat's differentiation vs. baxdrostat and those called out by AZN; 2) differences that matter in Launch- HTN's study design/patient characteristics vs. BaxHTN; 3) lourndrostat's interaction with PPIs; 4) what could potentially be shown on each drugs' product label; 5) timing of baxdrostat's NDA submission; and 6) commercial opportunity in HTN and key challenges. During AZN's webinar, mgmt expects baxdrostat's NDA submission by YE25 to support a potential launch in 2026. AZN also noted that baxdrostat's second Ph. 3 study (Bax24) is now complete and results could be available in the coming weeks and followed by a detailed presentation at a conference later this year. However, AZN notably declined to comment when asked during its webinar whether Bax24's results will be included in baxdrostat's NDA submission. It's also unclear whether baxdrostat's NDA filing could come ahead of lourndrostat's, as MLYS continues to not give further guidance beyond its pre- NDA meeting with the FDA in 4Q25. Our key takeaways from our MLYS dinner NDR and AZN's webinar are summarized below.

Baxdrostat's BaxHTN results further validated the ASl class. MLYS believes baxdrostat's results further validated its core thesis that aldosterone plays a central, previously underestimated role in hypertension and cardiorenal disease. From the KOL's perspective, BaxHTN's results bolster confidence in ASIs as a class and were reassuring rather than surprising, while being broadly consistent with his expectations given MLYS's Launch- HTN data.

AZN's claims on baxdrostat's best- in- class profile are not scientifically justifiable in our view. AZN highlighted multiple advantages for baxdrostat, including: best- in- class efficacy at its week 12 primary endpoint, 2) no clinically relevant drug- drug interactions, 3) a longer half- life that supports better 24- hr control, and 4) durable effects in the randomized withdrawal portion of BaxHTN. However, we believe it is not scientifically justifiable nor credible to compare

Analysts employed by non- US affiliates are not registered/qualified as research analysts with

BaxHTN's week 12 results to Launch- HTN's week 6 primary endpoint when Launch- HTN's results at 12 weeks were also presented. Additionally, results across all relevant Ph. 3 trials including BaxHTN, Launch- HTN, and spironolactone's PATHWAY2 showed continued improvement in efficacy from 6 to 12 weeks. It is also unclear how baxdrostat's longer half- life provided any advantages over lorundrostat's shorter half- life given that Launch- HTN's SBP results were taken at the trough of lorundrostat plasma levels in the morning before next dose. Recall that MLYS does not expect rapid (95\%\) diuretic use, with similar ACE/ARB and CCB breakdown). However, Launch- HTN had a notably higher representation of Black patients ( \(\sim 27 - 32\%\) vs. BaxHTN's \(\sim 6 - 9\%\) across cohorts). MLYS also evaluated patients with lower eGFR between 30- 45 mL/min/1.73 m² in its Ph. 2 Explore- CKD study, which could be reflected in lorundrostat's label. The broader evidence could better support use of lorundrostat among clinicians especially when treating Black patients or those with comorbid HTN and CKD. Although the KOL was cautious on declaring a preference for either therapy since he participated in both Launch- HTN and BaxHTN studies, he acknowledged that lorundrostat's broader dataset could be more supportive while baxdrostat may be better positioned in Asian populations given their higher proportion in BaxHTN and the ongoing BaxAsia study.

Lorundrostat's interaction with PPls appears manageable and not a credible concern. Since lorundrostat's interaction with proton- pump inhibitors (PPIs) is not a safety issue and Launch- HON allowed the use of PPls, MLYS does not expect a contraindication with PPls, its label. Note that lorundrostat's studies allowed mid- day PPI administration, following morning lorundrostat doses of up to 3 times/week. Physicians can also switch patients from PPI to H2 blockers with nighttime administration, which the KOL exercised for all of his patients in Launch- HON. Given lorundrostat also demonstrated comparable efficacy from the 25 mg QD dose in Explore- CKD (7.5 mmHg pbo- adj SBP reduction at week 4), MLYS believes patients on PPls could still achieve meaningful benefit even if the 50 mg QD dose has a reduced absorption by \(\sim 50\%\) due to PPls. Additionally, the KOL does not anticipate significant real- world issues from PPI interactions and noted the waning popularity of PPls, where his practice has reduced prescribing by \(\sim 75\%\) over the past few years due to increased risks from long- term use (Clostridium difficile, pneumonia, bone fractures, CKD, abdominal pain, diarrhea, etc.). Note that MLYS has not completed a PPI subgroup analysis but is considering a post- hoc analysis in the future.

Both baxdrostat and lorundrostat labels may include multiple dose levels. Despite minimal separation in placebo- adj SBP efficacy response for 1 mg and 2 mg doses of baxdrostat at week 12 in BaxHTN, AZN plans to advance both doses to allow individualized balancing of efficacy and tolerability. The KOL agreed that multiple dosing options are beneficial for clinicians. MLYS also believes that baxdrostat could be approved with two doses where the 50 mg QD will be the starting dose for most patients and the 25 mg QD could be used as the starting dose for special populations with lower eGFR or down- titration for the 50 mg dose.

Uncertainty around the size and composition of baxdrostat's safety database are potential risks. MLYS is collecting 52- week safety data from lorundrostat's OLE studies and plans to include data from \(>50\%\) of patients at filing. The remainder of data can be provided within the 120- day safety update period. Contrarily, BaxHTN's four- part design allowed some patients to receive continuous 52- week treatment that could be used to satisfy FDA's safety database requirements. However, it's unclear how many patients are needed to satisfy the FDA's safety requirements given its NEJM publication suggested only 245 patients continued into Part 4. Note that MLYS enrolled \(>1.3K\) across pivotal studies who were eligible for OLE and could have many more patients than AZN. While patients from baxdrostat's Ph. 2 HALO- OLE could potentially contribute, MLYS believes filing with a smaller safety database could have higher regulatory risk. MLYS did not comment on the specific number of patients it is targeting for lorundrostat's filing, but confirmed it will be thoughtful in its execution to avoid future regulatory delays or potential CRL.

MLYS believes AZN's \(\) 2.5B+\(peak sales target for HTN is a conservative and achievable target with room for upside. MLYS's market research suggests that there are \~10M patients on 3+ AHTS and another \~10M patients on 2 AHTS, indicating that only modest penetration would be needed to reach AZN's peak sales estimates at an assumed \~\) 4,500 net price (using SGLT2 inhibitors as analog). MLYS also referenced recent IQVIA data suggesting that \~8M 3L+ patients try a

new therapy each year, of which \(\sim 5M\) are in the \(4L+\) setting. The analysis also found that no products had \(>10\%\) market share, underscoring a highly fragmented HTN market. The KOL estimated that \(\sim 10 - 30\%\) of patients have difficult- to- control SBP on three or more agents, further reinforcing the unmet need for new therapies.

Despite broad optimism for ASIs, AZN highlighted a few initial challenges. Through its discussions with physicians and payers, AZN believes the long- term costs associated with uHTN/HTN and poor tolerability to spironolactone are well recognized. It also views that the lowering of guideline SBP targets to \(130 \text{mmHg}\) (or \(120 \text{mmHg}\) in some patients) as favorable tailwinds for new ASI therapies. However, it also called out a few key challenges. The first is that many difficult- to- control HTN patients are managed primarily in general practice, underscoring the need for clear referral pathways and timely escalation to specialists. Additionally, securing Medicare Part D access in the \(3L+\) setting will be critical since most HTN patients are \(>60\) years. Note that among US patients on three or more AHTS, MLYS estimates the payer mix is approximately \(60\%\) Medicare and \(40\%\) commercial.
Pre- NDA meeting in 4Q25Expected NDA filing in early 2026Ph. 2 Explore- OSA topline results for overweight/obese patients with moderate- to- severe OSA + HTN in 1H26

Baxdrostat (AZN)  - Baxdrostat NDA filing by YE25  - Ph. 3 Bax24 data in \(4L+\) rHTN in 2H25  - Ph. 3 BaxAsia in \(3L+\) uHTN/rHTN in 2026  - Ph. 3 BaxDuo- Arctic uHTN + CKD ongoing (PCD Dec. 2027)  - Ph. 3 BaxDuo- Pacific outcomes study ongoing (PCD Apr. 2030)  - Ph. 3 PREVENT- HF outcomes study in ongoing (PCD Dec. 2029)
Ph. 3 EASI- KIDNEY trial in CKD ongoing (PCD in Jan. 2029)
Ph. 3 CVOT study initiation in 2H25

Valuation: Our \(32,12\) - month price target for MLYS is based on: 1) an \(85\%\) weighting to a DCF analysis that assumes a WACC of \(17\%\) and a terminal growth rate (TGR) of \(0\%\) , which indicates an intrinsic value of \(31, and 2) a\) 15% weighting to a theoretical M&A valuation that assumes an 11x sales multiple applied to our risk- adjusted 2030E sales.

Risks: Key downside risks include lower than expected commercial opportunity forlorundrostat; safety concerns, including hyperkalemia; inability to show differentiated efficacy vs. competitors' pivotal studies; pipeline risks associated with being a single- asset company; liquidity/funding difficulties in developing lorundrostat; negative feedback/rejection of future regulatory submissions in the US/EU; inability to secure an established commercial partner; pricing and reimbursement challenges.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Certain transactions, including those involving futures, options, and other derivatives, give rise to substantial risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should review current options and futures disclosure documents which are available from Goldman Sachs sales representatives or at https://www.theocc.com/about/publications/character- risks.jsp and https://www.goldmansachs.com/disclosures/cftc_fom_disclosures. Transaction costs may be significant in option strategies calling for multiple purchase and sales of options such as spreads. Supporting documentation will be supplied upon request.

Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
Disclosure information is also available at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html or from Research Compliance, 200 West Street, New York, NY 10282.

You are permitted to store, display, analyze, modify, reformat, and print the information made available to you via this service only for your own use. You may not resell or reverse engineer this information to calculate or develop any index for disclosure and/or marketing or create any other derivative works or commercial product(s), data or offering(s) without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. You are not permitted to publish, transmit, or otherwise reproduce this information, in whole or in part, in any format to any third party without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. This foregoing restriction includes, without limitation, using, extracting, downloading or retrieving this information, in whole or in part, to train or finetune a machine learning or artificial intelligence system, or to provide or reproduce this information, in whole or in part, as a prompt or input to any such system.
